channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Welcomes Trump’s Syria Withdrawal: ‘Donald’s Right’
item.description: The Russian president said he broadly agreed that the Islamic State had been defeated in Syria. “Donald’s right, and I agree with him,” he said of President Trump.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Kurdish Fighters Discuss Releasing 3,200 ISIS Prisoners
item.media:description: Troops from the Syrian Democratic Forces at a funeral for fellow fighters in September. The Kurdish group has fought the Islamic State with American support.
item.description: Upset by President Trump’s order to withdraw troops, and expecting a Turkish attack, the Syrian Democratic Forces are considering freeing fighters, a monitoring group and official said.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Gatwick Airport Closed After Drone Flights That Officials Call ‘Deliberate’
item.media:description: Passengers in the South Terminal at Gatwick Airport on Thursday after drones flying illegally over the airfield led to the closing of the airport starting on Wednesday night.
item.description: Flights in and out of London’s second-busiest airport were halted after drones were spotted flying illegally nearby, with passengers diverted to airports as far away as Paris.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG and DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: 3 More Held in Killing of Tourists in Morocco; Denmark Denounces ‘Act of Terror’
item.media:description: Villagers in Imlil, Morocco, near the site where the bodies of two Scandinavian tourists visiting the Atlas Mountains were found.
item.description: The bodies of Louisa Vesterager Jespersen, 24, of Denmark and Maren Ueland, 28, of Norway were found by other tourists in an isolated area of the High Atlas Mountains.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN SELSOE SORENSEN and AIDA ALAMI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: France’s Yellow Vests Reveal a Crisis of Mobility in All Its Forms
item.media:description: The so-called Yellow Vest movement takes its name from the Day-Glo vests that French motorists are required to keep in their vehicles. That’s no accident.
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.description: Mobility is the story of globalization and its inequities. But it is more than trains and automobiles: It includes social and economic movement, too.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: Chinese Authorities Identify Third Canadian Detained in Diplomatic Spat
item.media:description: The Canadian Embassy in Beijing. The arrest of a senior executive for the Chinese tech giant Huawei has provoked a continuing diplomatic crisis between China and Canada.
item.description: A teacher from Alberta, Sarah D. McIver, is the latest Canadian to be detained by China, which appears to be pressuring Canada to release a Chinese executive.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Dutch Consider Taking Russia to Court Over Downing of Jet Over Ukraine
item.media:description: A commemoration in 2014 of the 298 people killed aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.
item.description: In a letter, the Netherlands’ foreign minister said that Russia had rebuffed talks about a possible settlement for the victims of a civilian plane shot down over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Der Spiegel Fires Award-Winning Writer, Citing Fabrication on ‘Grand Scale’
item.description: Claas Relotius, a writer for the German magazine Der Spiegel, was fired after he admitted inventing quotations and characters in at least 14 articles.
item.dc:creator: ALAN YUHAS

item.title: China’s ‘Belt and Road’ Plan in Pakistan Takes a Military Turn
item.media:description: A Chinese rocket boosting two Pakistani satellites into orbit from Jiuquan, China, in July.
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.description: Under a program China insisted was peaceful, Pakistan is cooperating on distinctly defense-related projects, including a secret plan to build new fighter jets.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: Investors Are in Retreat, and the Poorest Countries Are Paying for It
item.media:description: The Radhe Industries cotton factory in Kadi, in the state of Gujarat. Indian cotton growers’ costs have been rising, but the prices they are getting for crops have plunged.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: As the Federal Reserve raises rates, global investors are pulling their money from emerging markets, damaging the world’s most vulnerable economies.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Couple Who Named Their Child After Hitler Are Sentenced for Neo-Nazi Membership
item.description: Adam Thomas, 22, and Claudia Patatas, 38, were convicted of being members of National Action, a violent far-right group banned in Britain since 2016.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Denmark, With an Eye on Muslims, Requires New Citizens to Shake Hands
item.media:description: Some Muslim and Jewish groups prohibit or discourage touching members of the opposite sex outside the immediate family.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: Lawmakers say the measure is aimed at those who refuse on religious grounds to touch members of the opposite sex. Some mayors plan to work around it.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN SELSOE SORENSEN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Taliban Talks Covered Fate of U.S. Military Presence in Afghanistan, Envoy Says
item.media:description: American troops in Logar province, Afghanistan, in August. The Taliban have refused to meet with Afghan officials until they reach agreements on troop withdrawal and other issues with the United States.
item.description: United States officials discussed the future of the American military presence in Afghanistan and an offer of a three-month cease-fire, an American diplomat said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Six Decapitated Seal Pups Found on New Zealand Beach
item.media:description: A fur seal pup in New Zealand. People have hurt or killed seals in the mistaken belief that they are responsible for low fish stocks, an official said.
item.description: Officials said people had hurt or killed seals before, in the mistaken belief that they are responsible for low fish stocks.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Congo Delays Presidential Election That Was Scheduled for Sunday
item.description: Amid violence, technical problems and an epidemic, officials said they were “technically incapable” of holding a vote to choose the first new leader in 18 years.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Egypt Acquits Democracy Workers in Case That Strained U.S. Ties
item.description: More than 40 Americans, Europeans and Egyptians were convicted in 2013, becoming symbols of the post-Arab Spring official backlash against civil society.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Hakuna Matata™? Can Companies Actually Trademark a Phrase Like That?
item.media:description: A “Lion King” float at Disneyland Paris. “The term ‘Hakuna Matata’ is not a Disney creation,” a petition notes, “hence not an infringement on intellectual or creative property, but an assault on the Swahili people and Africa as a whole.”
item.description: Yes, but Disney has been excoriated for trademarking the Swahili expression that became known worldwide thanks to “The Lion King.”
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: North Korea Says It Won’t Denuclearize Until U.S. Removes Threat
item.media:description: President Trump and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, shook hands in June on “complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula,” but not on the meaning of “complete” or “denuclearization.”
item.description: Diverging interpretations of exactly what “complete” and “denuclearization” mean have led to a diplomatic stalemate between Washington and Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Syria, Federal Reserve, Gatwick Airport: Your Thursday Briefing
item.media:description: U.S. troops in the northern Syrian city of Manbij in February.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Fed, Der Spiegel, Jeremy Corbyn: Your Thursday Briefing
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Paul Funk, second from the left, spoke to a Special Forces soldier outside the northern Syrian city of Manbij earlier this year.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: INYOUNG KANG

item.title: Facebook Rebuked for Failing to Disclose Data-Sharing Deals
item.media:description: A sign outside Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif. The social network faced sharp criticism after a New York Times article revealed details about its extensive data partnerships.
item.description: Lawmakers and others criticized the social network after a New York Times report revealed Facebook gave its partners extensive access to user data.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL LaFORGIA, NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and GABRIEL J.X. DANCE

item.title: U.S. Exit Seen as a Betrayal of the Kurds, and a Boon for ISIS
item.media:description: American Army vehicles supporting the Syrian Democratic Forces in Hajin, in eastern Syria, last week. President Trump has ordered their withdrawal.
item.description: President Trump’s order for American troops to withdraw from Syria leaves behind a crucial ally in the fight against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Syria, Facebook, Interest Rates: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Alexander Perepilichny, Russian Whistle-Blower, Likely Died of Natural Causes, Coroner Rules
item.description: Despite earlier indications of poisoning, a British coroner ruled that a key witness in the Magnitsky fraud case in fact had died of natural causes.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Deep Beneath Your Feet, They Live in the Octillions
item.media:description: An unidentified nematode, found in the Kopanang gold mine in South Africa, lives nearly a mile below the surface.
item.media:credit: Gaetan Borgonie, Extreme Life Isyensya, Belgium
item.description: The real journey to the center of the Earth has begun, and scientists are discovering subsurface microbial beings that shake up what we think we know about life.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Renzo Piano Design Will Replace Collapsed Bridge in Genoa
item.media:description: Renzo Piano, left, and the mayor of Genoa, Marco Bucci, with a plan for a new bridge in in September.
item.description: The design by the Genoan-born architect features 43 lamps to honor the 43 victims of the Morandi Bridge collapse last summer.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: ‘The Criminals Are Winning’: Londoners on the Police Response to Minor Crimes
item.media:description: London’s Metropolitan Police are severely stretched and struggling to reach their target times for responding to reports of crimes.
item.description: The London police make an arrest in 4 percent of domestic burglaries in the city. Victims and witnesses speak up about their experiences.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Israel Calls for International Action Against Hezbollah Tunnels
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers lift the cover of a hole leading into a cross-border tunnel from Lebanon into Israel.
item.description: Israel’s military exposed a fourth tunnel from Lebanon, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made the case for United Nations action.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: China Holds Third Canadian, Escalating Diplomatic Crisis With the United States
item.media:description: The Canadian detentions appear to be retaliation for Canada’s arrest of Meng Wanzhou, chief financial officer of Huawei.
item.description: The detentions of three Canadian citizens appear to be retaliation for Canada’s arrest of a top Chinese executive at the behest of the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Pope Ousts Los Angeles Bishop After Allegation of Misconduct with a Minor
item.media:description: An auxiliary bishop of Los Angeles, Alexander Salazar, has resigned after an accusation of misconduct with a minor in the 1990s was found to be credible.
item.media:credit: Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.description: An investigation by the Los Angeles archdiocese found an accusation against Bishop Alexander Salazar to be credible. The bishop denies wrongdoing.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith

item.title: Did Jeremy Corbyn Call Theresa May ‘a Stupid Woman’?
item.description: A camera captured Britain’s opposition leader mouthing several words after being harangued by the prime minister. Her party’s lawmakers are demanding an apology.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Secret Santa Leaves 2-Year-Old Girl Gifts for the Next 14 Christmases
item.media:description: “Christmas Eve at the Mellops’,” by Tomi Ungerer, was one of the presents a Welsh girl received from her deceased neighbor.
item.description: A man in Wales regaled Twitter with the tale of a now-deceased neighbor organizing presents for his daughter until she is 16.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Trump Withdraws U.S. Forces From Syria, Declaring ‘We Have Won Against ISIS’
item.media:description: American Special Forces soldiers in February in northern Syria. “Our boys, our young women, our men — they’re all coming back, and they’re coming back now,” President Trump declared in a video posted Wednesday evening on Twitter.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The president overruled his military and diplomatic advisers, who warned against abandoning Kurdish allies and ceding influence in Syria to Russia and Iran.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER, HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: ‘I Can English Understand,’ New Official Says. The Swiss Have Their Doubts.
item.media:description: Guy Parmelin, center, is set to become economy minister, a job that involves negotiating international trade accords.
item.description: Guy Parmelin is set to become economy minister, a job that involves negotiating international trade accords.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Italy and E.U. Reach a Budget Deal, as Populist Plan Runs Into Reality
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte of Italy in Brussels last week. After months of defiance, his government agreed to lower debt and avoid financial penalties.
item.description: After months of refusals to back down, the government blinked, saying it would shave billions of euros off its budget to avoid financial penalties from the E.U.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: U.S. Will Review Travel Ban on North Korea, Envoy Says
item.media:description: Stephen Biegun, United States special representative for North Korea, and Foreign Minister Kang Kyung-wha of South Korea in Seoul in October. Mr. Biegun said he would meet with American aid groups, who say sanctions enforcement is hindering their work in the North.
item.description: Washington announced the possible shift as it seeks to break the logjam in talks on denuclearizing North Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Facebook, Criminal Justice, Federal Reserve: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook at a Senate hearing in April, when he assured lawmakers that people “have complete control” over what they share on the social network.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: That Punishing Blockade? ‘We’ve Moved On,’ Qatar Says
item.media:description: Qatar’s emir, Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, waving as he arrives to attend a military parade in the capital, Doha.
item.description: After its larger neighbors began a blockade of the tiny Gulf state, Qatar retooled its economy, beefed up its military and adjusted to the new reality.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: She Wouldn’t Promise Not to Boycott Israel, So a Texas School District Stopped Paying Her
item.media:description: A demonstration in New York City in 2016.
item.media:credit: Erik McGregor/Pacific Press, via LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.description: A speech pathologist’s lawsuit is part of a broader debate in the United States over efforts to boycott, divest investments from, and place sanctions on Israel.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Update: Oslo Puts Up a Stop Sign
item.media:description: Oslo is making its city center more accommodating to cyclists and pedestrians by severely restricting access by cars
item.description: Starting in 2019, the Norwegian capital will restrict the use of vehicles in its city center, following a global trend to make popular tourist destinations more pedestrian-friendly.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WOLFE

item.title: Chinese City Bans Christmas Displays Amid Religious Crackdown
item.media:description: Workers set up Christmas decorations outside a Louis Vuitton store in Beijing on Friday.
item.description: In this Chinese city, the War on Christmas is over. And Christmas lost.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY

item.title: Lens: Spices. Soil. Worn Photos. These Are the Objects Unidentified Migrants Left Behind.
item.description: Rocco Rorandelli captures the lives of the refugees and migrants who died crossing a river between Turkey and Greece through the things they carried
item.dc:creator: EVELYN NIEVES and ROCCO RORANDELLI

item.title: Not Just Khashoggi: Reprisal Killings of Journalists Surged This Year
item.media:description: A symbolic funeral prayer in Istanbul for Jamal Khashoggi, the Saudi columnist for The Washington Post who was killed and dismembered in October. He was one of at least 34 journalists who were killed because of their work in 2018, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists.
item.description: At least 53 journalists were killed worldwide in 2018, most of them targeted because of their work, the Committee to Protect Journalists said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Facebook, Michael Flynn, Mourinho: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France met with Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, in May.
item.media:credit: Christophe Petit Tesson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: INYOUNG KANG

item.title: In Home Village of Girl Who Died in U.S. Custody, Poverty Drives Migration
item.media:description: Claudia Maquin, with her six-month-old daughter Angela, near Raxruhá, Guatemala. Her other daughter, Jakelin, died in American custody after crossing the border this month.
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.description: Jakelin Caal Maquin, a 7-year-old girl who died in the custody of American officials, came from a poor Guatemalan village where many see emigration as the only escape from poverty.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Cuba Eliminates Language About Same-Sex Marriage From Draft of New Constitution
item.description: After pushback from evangelical churches and citizens, the commission revising the Constitution said it would eliminate the language “as a way of respecting all opinions.”
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: As Facebook Raised a Privacy Wall, It Carved an Opening for Tech Giants
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, at a Senate hearing in April. Internal Facebook records describe data-sharing deals that benefited more than 150 companies.
item.description: Internal documents show that the social network gave Microsoft, Amazon, Spotify and others far greater access to people’s data than it has disclosed.
item.dc:creator: GABRIEL J.X. DANCE, MICHAEL LaFORGIA and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

item.title: Ukraine Wins New I.M.F. Support as Tensions Rise With Russia
item.media:description: President Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine with the managing director of the I.M.F., Christine Lagarde, during their meeting at the I.M.F. headquarters in Washington last year.
item.description: The International Monetary Fund agreed to a $3.9 billion line of credit for Ukraine, whose economy has struggled with corruption and a conflict with Russia.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
